item.title: Defect-Free Growth of Decagonal Quasicrystals around Obstacles
item.description:
Author(s): Kelly L. Wang, Insung Han, Domagoj Fijan, Sharon C. Glotzer, and Ashwin J. Shahani

Large-scale obstacles to crystal growth can throw the whole lattice off kilter, but quasicrystals can accommodate them without losing their atomic-scale order.


[Phys. Rev. Lett. 135, 166203] Published Fri Oct 17, 2025
item.content:encoded:
Author(s): Kelly L. Wang, Insung Han, Domagoj Fijan, Sharon C. Glotzer, and Ashwin J. Shahani

Large-scale obstacles to crystal growth can throw the whole lattice off kilter, but quasicrystals can accommodate them without losing their atomic-scale order.


[Phys. Rev. Lett. 135, 166203] Published Fri Oct 17, 2025
item.dc:title: Defect-Free Growth of Decagonal Quasicrystals around Obstacles
item.dc:creator: Kelly L. Wang, Insung Han, Domagoj Fijan, Sharon C. Glotzer, and Ashwin J. Shahani

item.title: Critical Gate Distance for Wigner Crystallization in the Two-Dimensional Electron Gas
item.description:
Author(s): Agnes Valenti, Vladimir Calvera, Yubo Yang (杨煜波), Miguel A. Morales, Steven A. Kivelson, Ilya Esterlis, and Shiwei Zhang

The Wigner crystal phase in two-dimensional electron gas is unstable at all densities when gate electrodes are sufficiently close.


[Phys. Rev. Lett. 135, 166501] Published Fri Oct 17, 2025
item.content:encoded:
Author(s): Agnes Valenti, Vladimir Calvera, Yubo Yang (杨煜波), Miguel A. Morales, Steven A. Kivelson, Ilya Esterlis, and Shiwei Zhang

The Wigner crystal phase in two-dimensional electron gas is unstable at all densities when gate electrodes are sufficiently close.


[Phys. Rev. Lett. 135, 166501] Published Fri Oct 17, 2025
item.dc:title: Critical Gate Distance for Wigner Crystallization in the Two-Dimensional Electron Gas

item.title: Macroscopic Suppression of Supersonic Quantum Transport
item.description:
Author(s): Jérémy Faupin, Marius Lemm, Israel Michael Sigal, and Jingxuan Zhang (张景宣)

We consider a broad class of strongly interacting quantum lattice gases, including the Fermi-Hubbard and Bose-Hubbard models. We focus on macroscopic particle clusters of size $θN$, with $θ∈(0,1)$ and $N$ the total particle number, and we study the quantum probability that such a cluster is transpor…


[Phys. Rev. Lett. 135, 160405] Published Thu Oct 16, 2025
item.content:encoded:
Author(s): Jérémy Faupin, Marius Lemm, Israel Michael Sigal, and Jingxuan Zhang (张景宣)

We consider a broad class of strongly interacting quantum lattice gases, including the Fermi-Hubbard and Bose-Hubbard models. We focus on macroscopic particle clusters of size θN, with θ∈(0,1) and N the total particle number, and we study the quantum probability that such a cluster is transported ac…


[Phys. Rev. Lett. 135, 160405] Published Thu Oct 16, 2025
item.dc:title: Macroscopic Suppression of Supersonic Quantum Transport

item.title: Selective Excitation of Collective Modes in Multiband Superconductor ${\mathrm{MgB}}_{2}$
item.description:
Author(s): Jiayu Yuan, Liyu Shi, Tiequan Xu, Yue Wang, Zizhao Gan, Hao Wang, Tianyi Wu, Dong Wu, Tao Dong, and Nanlin Wang

Recent developments in nonequilibrium and nonlinear terahertz (THz) spectroscopies have significantly advanced the understanding of collective excitations in superconductors. However, there is ongoing debate regarding the identification of Higgs, Leggett modes, and BCS charge fluctuations in the two…


[Phys. Rev. Lett. 135, 166002] Published Wed Oct 15, 2025

item.title: Superconductivity at 28 K in Sodium Graphite Intercalation Compound under High Pressure
item.description:
Author(s): Guangchen Ma, Yingying Wang, Zefang Wang, Yuki Nakamoto, Katsuya Shimizu, Guangtao Liu, Mi Zhou, Hongbo Wang, Pengyue Gao, and Yanming Ma

The discovery of 15.1 K superconductivity in first-stage ${\mathrm{CaC}}_{6}$ reignited interest in searching for high-temperature superconductors in graphite intercalation compounds (GICs). However, despite nearly two decades of intensive research, progress in exploring high-temperature superconduc…


[Phys. Rev. Lett. 135, 166003] Published Wed Oct 15, 2025
item.content:encoded:
Author(s): Guangchen Ma, Yingying Wang, Zefang Wang, Yuki Nakamoto, Katsuya Shimizu, Guangtao Liu, Mi Zhou, Hongbo Wang, Pengyue Gao, and Yanming Ma

The discovery of 15.1 K superconductivity in first-stage CaC6 reignited interest in searching for high-temperature superconductors in graphite intercalation compounds (GICs). However, despite nearly two decades of intensive research, progress in exploring high-temperature superconductivity in GIC ma…


[Phys. Rev. Lett. 135, 166003] Published Wed Oct 15, 2025

Elucidating the mechanisms of negative thermal expansion (NTE) not only identifies the determining factors of this phenomenon but also provides guidance for the precise regulation of the coefficient of thermal expansion (CTE). However, accurately quantifying these determining factors during CTE modu…

Unconventional superconductors that spontaneously break space-group symmetries of their underlying crystal lattice are distinguished by spatial modulations of superconducting order parameter. These states have recently captured significant attention in various strongly correlated materials, where th…

item.title: Unconventional Hall Effect in Gapless Superconductors: Transverse Supercurrent Converted from Normal Current
item.description:
Author(s): Miaomiao Wei, Longjun Xiang, Fuming Xu, Bin Wang, and Jian Wang

A normal metal proximitized by a superconductor can exhibit a gapless superconducting state characterized by segmented Fermi surfaces, as confirmed experimentally. In this state, quasiparticle states remain gapless along one direction, while a superconducting gap opens in the perpendicular direction…


[Phys. Rev. Lett. 135, 166304] Published Wed Oct 15, 2025
item.content:encoded:
Author(s): Miaomiao Wei, Longjun Xiang, Fuming Xu, Bin Wang, and Jian Wang

A normal metal proximitized by a superconductor can exhibit a gapless superconducting state characterized by segmented Fermi surfaces, as confirmed experimentally. In this state, quasiparticle states remain gapless along one direction, while a superconducting gap opens in the perpendicular direction…


[Phys. Rev. Lett. 135, 166304] Published Wed Oct 15, 2025
item.dc:title: Unconventional Hall Effect in Gapless Superconductors: Transverse Supercurrent Converted from Normal Current

Structured optical cavities have advanced as a powerful test bed to study lattice Hamiltonians in general, and topological phenomena in particular. The in situ tuning of topological modes, enabled via substantial modifications of emulated lattice potentials, has remained out of experimental reach du…

item.title: Phase Matching of High Harmonic Generation in Twisted van der Waals Crystals
item.description:

A strategy for phase matching high-harmonic generation with arbitrary harmonic orders in crystals enables the development of ultrashort-wavelength and ultrafast-pulse laser sources in tabletop systems.

item.title: Two-Dimensional Topological Edge States in Periodic Space-Time Interfaces
item.description:
Author(s): Ohad Segal, Yonatan Plotnik, Eran Lustig, Yonatan Sharabi, Moshe-Ishay Cohen, Alexander Dikopoltsev, and Mordechai Segev

Topological edge states in systems of two (or more) dimensions offer scattering-free transport, exhibiting robustness to inhomogeneities and disorder. In a different domain, time-modulated systems, such as photonic time crystals, offer nonresonant amplification drawing energy from the modulation. Co…


[Phys. Rev. Lett. 135, 163801] Published Tue Oct 14, 2025

item.title: Dissipative Superfluidity in a Molecular Bose-Einstein Condensate
item.description:
Author(s): Hongchao Li, Xie-Hang Yu, Masaya Nakagawa, and Masahito Ueda

Motivated by recent experimental realization of a Bose-Einstein condensate (BEC) of dipolar molecules, we develop superfluid transport theory for a dissipative BEC to show that a weak uniform two-body loss can induce phase rigidity, leading to superfluid transport of bosons without repulsive interac…


[Phys. Rev. Lett. 135, 166001] Published Tue Oct 14, 2025
item.content:encoded:
Author(s): Hongchao Li, Xie-Hang Yu, Masaya Nakagawa, and Masahito Ueda

Motivated by recent experimental realization of a Bose-Einstein condensate (BEC) of dipolar molecules, we develop superfluid transport theory for a dissipative BEC to show that a weak uniform two-body loss can induce phase rigidity, leading to superfluid transport of bosons without repulsive interac…


[Phys. Rev. Lett. 135, 166001] Published Tue Oct 14, 2025

item.title: Altermagnets with Topological Order in Kitaev Bilayers
item.description:
Author(s): Aayush Vijayvargia, Ezra Day-Roberts, Antia S. Botana, and Onur Erten

Building on recent advancements in altermagnetism, we develop a highly frustrated magnetic model with Kitaev-like interactions that integrates key aspects of both quantum spin liquids and altermagnets. While the ground state is a gapless quantum spin liquid, our analysis indicates that an altermagne…


[Phys. Rev. Lett. 135, 166701] Published Tue Oct 14, 2025
item.content:encoded:
Author(s): Aayush Vijayvargia, Ezra Day-Roberts, Antia S. Botana, and Onur Erten

Building on recent advancements in altermagnetism, we develop a highly frustrated magnetic model with Kitaev-like interactions that integrates key aspects of both quantum spin liquids and altermagnets. While the ground state is a gapless quantum spin liquid, our analysis indicates that an altermagne…


[Phys. Rev. Lett. 135, 166701] Published Tue Oct 14, 2025

item.title: Uniaxial-Pressure Control of Excitonic Fluctuations and Monoclinic Distortions in ${\mathrm{Ta}}_{2}{\mathrm{NiSe}}_{5}$
item.description:
Author(s): X. Shi, Y.-S. Zhang, D. Huang, M. Isobe, H. Takagi, B. Keimer, and A. V. Boris

Collective many-body effects are shown to enhance exciton fluctuations even when monoclinic distortions are diminished by uniaxial pressure, supporting the excitonic origin of the phase transition in Ta2NiSe5.


[Phys. Rev. Lett. 135, 156503] Published Thu Oct 09, 2025
item.content:encoded:
Author(s): X. Shi, Y.-S. Zhang, D. Huang, M. Isobe, H. Takagi, B. Keimer, and A. V. Boris

Collective many-body effects are shown to enhance exciton fluctuations even when monoclinic distortions are diminished by uniaxial pressure, supporting the excitonic origin of the phase transition in Ta2NiSe5.


[Phys. Rev. Lett. 135, 156503] Published Thu Oct 09, 2025
item.dc:title: Uniaxial-Pressure Control of Excitonic Fluctuations and Monoclinic Distortions in ${\mathrm{Ta}}_{2}{\mathrm{NiSe}}_{5}$
item.dc:creator: X. Shi, Y.-S. Zhang, D. Huang, M. Isobe, H. Takagi, B. Keimer, and A. V. Boris
